Values represent the mean AMOC strength and BF3 strength averaged over each period indicated. r indicates the Pearson’s correlation coefficient, while p indicates its respective p-value. The observational estimate was excluded from the correlation analysis.Full size imageAs GHGs emissions directly warm the atmosphere and cause sea-ice and ice sheet melt, they drive an AMOC weakening through direct thermal forcing and indirectly through freshwater input. There is observational evidence that AMOC has been weakening since the mid-twentieth century26,27,45, and subpolar North Atlantic freshening could have played a major role in this weakening25. However, under intensified anthropogenic warming, the 21st-century AMOC weakening will likely be primarily driven by thermal forcing25,50,52,53. Nevertheless, the future contribution of meltwater is highly uncertain54. Our results suggest that a 50% AMOC weakening by 2100 (access-fw; Supplementary Fig. 5), in which approximately 70% is attributed to thermal forcing25, leads to a 60% reduction in the upwelling feedback. If considering the thermal forcing only (access-cmip), the AMOC slows down by 35%, while the upwelling feedback reduces by 33%.DiscussionOur results show that an AMOC weakening reduces the eastern equatorial Atlantic SST variability through two distinct but complementary mechanisms: (1) inducing an atmospheric teleconnection by intensifying the subtropical high-pressure system in the North Atlantic and leading to weaker equatorial trade winds, thus contributing to reduced zonal advection and upwelling feedbacks (Fig. 5); (2) triggering an oceanic teleconnection through the propagation of Kelvin waves from the subpolar Atlantic Ocean that, upon reaching the equatorial region, deepens the thermocline, thereby weakening the Atlantic Niño feedbacks, with major influence on the local upwelling feedback (Fig. 5). Taken together, both atmospheric and oceanic teleconnections described here contribute to a better understanding of the driving processes associated with thermocline-surface decoupling in the equatorial Atlantic.Fig. 5: Oceanic and atmospheric teleconnections from an AMOC decline to the equatorial Atlantic.Shading represents differences in sea surface temperature (top panel) and ocean temperature (bottom panel) between the end of the century (2080–2099) and the pre-industrial period (1850–1890) in the SSP5-8.5 experiments, including freshwater discharge (access-fw). Changes in deep-water formation in the subarctic Atlantic, driven by ocean heat uptake and ice sheet melt due to anthropogenic warming, trigger two teleconnection processes to the equatorial Atlantic: (1) intensified atmospheric circulation in the North Atlantic and southward ITCZ shift, in response to reduced northward oceanic heat transport, reduce the intensity of the equatorial trades, flattening the equatorial thermocline and weakening the Bjerknes Feedbacks; (2) displaced isopycnals in the subpolar North Atlantic trigger downwelling Kelvin waves that travel southward along the western boundary of the North Atlantic and cross the equator, promoting further deepening of the thermocline and contributing to the decoupling between oceanic and atmospheric processes.Full size imageThe AMOC is projected to decline under all global warming scenarios55. However, there are large uncertainties associated with projecting the changes in AMOC intensity throughout the twenty-first century56. These uncertainties stem from various factors, including different global warming scenarios55, systematic model biases, ice sheet melt25 and internal climate dynamics57,58. As such, the projected Atlantic Niño decline will likely be tied to the rate of the AMOC slow-down. The absence of interactive ice sheets in CMIP6 models likely underestimates the magnitude of the AMOC weakening25, thus possibly underestimating future Atlantic Niño decline. Finally, it is also important to understand the impact of changes in the South Atlantic Ocean on the equatorial Atlantic variability and what their combined impacts on precipitation will be.By accounting for subarctic meltwater in model simulations, we identify a potential weakening of 60 ± 6% in the eastern Atlantic upwelling feedback by the end of the century. A deepened thermocline and reduced upwelling variability in the eastern equatorial Atlantic can lead to weaker and less frequent ventilation of surface waters, impacting nutrient availability and thus tropical Atlantic fishery productivity. The shift of Atlantic Niño anomalies to the central Atlantic would reverse its impact on Eastern Africa coastal cities, while diminishing its influence on Amazon rainfall variability.MethodsEarth System modelIn this study, we use the Australian Community Climate and Earth System Simulator version 1.5 (ACCESS-ESM1.5)28, a fully coupled model comprising atmospheric, oceanic, land and sea ice sub-models. The atmospheric component is the UK Met Office Unified Model (UM) version 7.359 configured at 1.875∘ longitude by 1.25∘ latitude with 38 vertical levels, extending from the surface to 40 km. The land component, which includes biogeochemistry, is the CABLE model60 and is directly coupled to the atmospheric model. The oceanic component is the Modular Ocean Model version 5 (MOM5)61 from the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory of the United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA-GFDL). The horizontal ocean grid has a nominal resolution of 1∘. The latitudinal resolution is higher at the equator (0.33∘) and in the Southern Ocean (0.4∘ at 70∘S). This component has 50 vertical levels, with 20 evenly spaced levels (10 metres in the first 200 metres of the water column). The sea ice component is the Los Alamos National Laboratory CICE model version 4.162, which runs on the same grid as the ocean model.Idealised meltwater experimentsACCESS-ESM1.5 is spun up under CMIP6 pre-industrial setup for 1,000 years31. From this state, a meltwater experiment is conducted by adding 0.4 Sv (1 Sv = 106 m3. s−1) of freshwater uniformly in the subpolar North Atlantic (50∘N to 70∘N) for 500 years. Although this forcing lacks realism, it’s valuable for studying climate impacts resulting from an AMOC collapse. Throughout the simulation, atmospheric CO2 concentration remains constant at the pre-industrial level (i.e., 284ppm), ensuring that any observed variations are solely due to the climatic effects of freshwater input. In this study, the control run under pre-industrial conditions is named AMOC-on, while the period at which AMOC stabilizes at around 3 Sv is referred to as AMOC-off.Historical and future projection experimentsWe use a 10-member ensemble of CMIP6 historical simulations from the ACCESS-ESM1.5 model63. These simulations incorporate observed climate forcings such as greenhouse gases, aerosols, and changes in land use. Additionally, we perform an extra 8-member ensemble of historical simulations with freshwater input in the subpolar North Atlantic (59∘N-72∘N and 65∘W-22∘W). This region is smaller than the one used in ‘idealized’ experiments and focuses on meltwater and solid ice runoff from Greenland and Arctic glaciers. The freshwater input experimental design is based on the evolution of observation-based SST and salinity AMOC indices25,45,64, Greenland warming, sea-ice retreat and changes in Greenland surface mass balance (Supplementary Fig. 5). Meltwater forcing in these historical simulations begins in 1960 with a constant input of 0.05 Sv until 1989, corresponding to a rapid sea-ice retreat and Greenland warming trend65. From 1990 to 1999, observational data suggest a nearly constant sea-ice extent and no significant changes in Greenland surface mass balance. As such, no freshwater forcing is applied during this period. From 2000, observations indicate substantial Greenland warming and ice loss and a nearly 30% sea-ice retreat. 0.05 Sv freshwater input is thus applied between 2000 and 2004, increasing to 0.075 Sv from 2005 to 2014, which marks the end of the CMIP6 historical protocol. We note that our freshwater estimates (0 to 75 mSv) to the subarctic Atlantic are in agreement with observational estimates (5 to 63 mSv)49,66 over the same period; however, most of our fluxes (50 to 75 mSv) lie on the upper-end of observational estimates. Nonetheless, the historical simulations with freshwater can better capture the observed AMOC weakening trend since 195725 (Supplementary Fig. 5). To evaluate the projected impact of freshwater forcing, we use the high-emissions scenario (ssp585)67. This scenario simulates a continuous Greenland warming throughout the 21st century, but no meltwater flux or ice discharge due to the melting of the Greenland ice-sheet or Arctic glaciers is included. To evaluate a more realistic scenario, we consider a ssp585 experiment with a linear increase in freshwater input in the subpolar Atlantic. This is implemented through decadal increments of 0.025 Sv starting from 0.1 Sv in 2020. From 2014 to 2019, a freshwater input of 0.075 Sv is kept, corresponding to the forcing at the end of the historical simulations. The combined historical and ssp585 experiments with freshwater input are referred in the main text as access-fw, while standard CMIP6 ACCESS-ESM1.5 simulations of the same scenarios are referred as access-cmip. A full description and justification of historical and future projections experiments with freshwater input can be found in ref. 25.AMOC strengthComputed as the annual maximum stream function (Sv) at 26∘N in the North Atlantic OceanVariability of Atlantic NiñoMeasured by the standard deviation of the SSTa during June, July and August in the eastern equatorial Atlantic (ATL3; 3∘S-3∘N, 20∘W-0∘).ITCZ indexComputed as the precipitation weighted mean latitude using values greater than 50% of the precipitation maximum in the zonal mean over oceanic regions only33.Dynamical ocean-atmosphere feedbacksWe calculate the three primary components of Bjerknes Feedbacks (BF) involving SST, thermocline depth, and zonal surface winds to investigate the potential dynamical drivers of changes in the Atlantic Niño variability. The three components are determined using linear regression between the associated variables14,68. Three main feedbacks are given by: (1) zonal advection feedback: regression of eastern equatorial Atlantic (ATL3;3∘S-3∘N, 20∘W-0∘) SST anomalies in June, July and August (JJA) onto western equatorial Atlantic (ATL4;3∘S-3∘N, 40∘W-20∘W) zonal wind stress anomalies. (2) thermocline feedback: regression of equatorial thermocline slope (difference between the mean Z20 in ATL3 and ATL4) anomalies during JJA onto zonal wind stress anomalies over the ATL4 region during March, April and May (MAM). (3) upwelling feedback: regression of SSTa in ATL3 onto thermocline depth (depth of the 20∘C isotherm) anomalies in ATL3 in JJA.Thermal wind balanceThe Thermal wind equations relate the vertical velocity shear to horizontal density gradients. These equations can be derived from the horizontal geostrophic components. Assuming a small Rossby number, thin aspect ratio, Boussinesq approximation, Euler Equation and f-plane the Navier-Stokes equation becomes:$$-fu=\frac{1}{\rho }\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}$$
                    (1)
                $$fv=\frac{1}{\rho }\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}$$
                    (2)
                Where p(x, y, z) is the pressure, u(x, y, z) and v(x, y, z) are the zonal and meridional velocities respectively, ρ(x, y, z) is the seawater density and f in the Coriolis parameter on the f-plane. Taking the vertical derivative of equations (1) and (2), and estimating density from the hydrostatic balance, the geostrophic velocity shear is given by the thermal-wind balance:$$\frac{\partial v}{\partial z}=-\frac{g}{{\rho }_{0}f}\frac{\partial \rho }{\partial x}$$
                    (3)
                $$\frac{\partial u}{\partial z}=\frac{g}{{\rho }_{0}f}\frac{\partial \rho }{\partial y}$$
                    (4)
                where ρ0 is the reference density and g the gravitational acceleration. This relationship indicates that higher velocities occur in regions of intense horizontal density gradients. The propagation of Kelvin waves effectively modifies density gradients along the boundary (Supplementary Fig. 4a, c), thus affecting the velocities of boundary currents baroclinically (Supplementary Fig. 4b, d). In this analysis, the offshore vertical density gradient was removed in order to isolate the effect of the propagation of coastally trapped waves. Lastly, it is important to note that the amplitude of the Kelvin waves triggered by freshwater anomalies is dependent on the intensity of the anomaly at the western boundary. Sensitivity experiments indicate that the smaller freshwater input region (59-72∘N and 65∘W-22∘W), used in access-fw simulations, generates stronger density anomalies close to the western boundary and thus triggers Kelvin waves of higher amplitude than the ones generated by the broader input region used in the idealized experiment (50∘N-70∘N and 70∘W-0∘E). Noting that the majority of the observed meltwater input occurs in Baffin Bay and Davis Strait (at the western boundary)49, it is possible that while the idealized experiment underestimates the amplitude of the Kelvin waves, these are overestimated in access-fw simulations.

Data availability
              
              Observational SST data were downloaded from the United Kingdom Met Office repository (https://www.metoffice.gov.uk/hadobs/hadisst/). Gridded thermocline depth (depth of 20∘C isotherm) is available from the Ocean Reanalysis System Version 5 (ORA-S5) public repository (https://www.ecmwf.int/en/research/climate-reanalysis/ocean-reanalysis). AMOC estimates from the RAPID-array are available at https://rapid.ac.uk/. Satellite-based AMOC estimates can be obtained through direct contact with Dr.Eleonor Frajka-Williams (eleanor.frajka@uni-hamburg.de). ACCESS-ESM1.5 simulations performed under the CMIP6 project (piControl, historical and ssp585) are publicly available through the Earth System Grid Federation online repository.
            Code availability
              
              Computational code for the ACCESS-ESM1.5 model is available at the ARC CoE for Climate Extremes Computational Modelling Systems (https://github.com/coecms/access-esm). Computational codes for the data analyses performed in this study are available upon request from the corresponding author.
